Violin Maker Says Carving a Violin Similar to Rearing a Child
LaserPhotos NY306,307,308,309,310,311 on schedule for Dec. 23
DOC.TEXT: Severin Schurger spends weeks perfecting a violin, days just carving and eyeing the scroll of his creation to ensure its curves are even. ``Something I would like to achieve would be to make a nice scroll quickly,'' says Schurger, who studied playing and making violins in Japan, where his mentors could carve two perfectly shaped spruce scrolls a day. So carefully does he work that he carves just two or three violins a year out of spruce and maple, making about 25 violins, six violas and three cellos in 18 years. The instruments sell for about $6,000 each. ``I just sort of stopped practicing and I wanted to devote my life to repairing and making violins so other people can play. I had a passion for it. It's something I really enjoy.'' In addition to that passion, Schurger brought to the craft his experience as a cabinetmaker on sailboats. ``There's a big similarity between a sailboat and a violin,'' he says, likening a violin's bridge to a sailboat's mast, its scroll to the sailboat's decorative stem. Watching a violin take form is enjoyable, he says, but ``when I put the varnish on, that's when it comes alive. That's a real big turn-on.'' For fun, Schurger spends his free time with voice lessons and singing in a Miami opera company. But violins are his first love, and he equates each of his finished instruments to a child that's ready to leave home. ``I don't really get attached to one _ you can't. ... This thing you are making is going out on the world stage. It's like a part of yourself.''
